title: Here and there
description: Japanese contains four sets of words that are used for describing location. Similarly to English, the choice between these words depends on physical distance between the speaker, listener and the object. For objects and places that are near the speaker, we use こー words, they are the same as using "this" in English. For objects and places that are further from the speaker, but simultaneously near the listener, we utilize そー words, the Japanese equivalent of "that". If the object or place in question is far from both the speaker and the listener, we will resort to using the あー prefix. This variant does not have an English substitute, but is usually described in grammar books as "that over there", a rather corny definition. Lastly, if we want to ask about the whereabouts of an object or a place, we use words with the どー prefix.

utilizes.prerequisite: これ, それ, あれ, どれ
utilizes.description: Use these to refer to unspecified objects

utilizes.prerequisite: この, その, あの, どの
utilizes.description: Use these to refer to specific objects

utilizes.prerequisite: ここ, そこ, あそこ, どこ
utilizes.description: If you want to talk about places, use these

utilizes.prerequisite: こちら, そちら, あちら, どちら
utilizes.description: These are the polite equivalents of -こ and -れ groups
